evidence.text: On February 10, 2025, the Department announced a RIF of nearly 50% of IES staff... On March 11, 2025, the Department announced a RIF of nearly 90% of IES staff, ... The Department’s contract cancellations at IES ...

extracted.value: Federal contracts necessary for the collection, maintenance, and dissemination of educational data were cancelled on February 10, 2025, and a mass reduction in force of 90% of IES staff was announced on March 11, 2025, resulting in the loss of access to critical datasets such as NAEP, EDFacts, NPSAS, ELS, TIMSS, and the What Works Clearinghouse.

evidence.text: Without these contracts and staff reductions, IES and its Centers will not be able to collect, analyze, and disseminate critical datasets... Plaintiffs and their members will be harmed by lack of data.

extracted.value: These cancellations and staff reductions have prevented IES and its Centers from fulfilling statutory mandates to collect, analyze, and disseminate federal education data, causing irreparable harm to plaintiffs and their research members.

evidence.text: Under the APA, a court shall “hold unlawful and set aside agency action … found to be … in excess of statutory jurisdiction, authority, or limitations.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(C)

Through ESRA, Congress mandates that the Department, through IES and its Centers, collect, collate, analyze, and report complete statistics on the condition of American education; 20 U.S.C. §§ 9541–48
ESRA further requires that all IES data remain available to the public through online channels. 20 U.S.C. § 9574
ESRA... that IES and its Centers are created by ESRA and cannot be abolished, dismantled, or closed by the President or Secretary. 20 U.S.C. § 9511
U.S. Const. art. I, §§ 1, 4 Violation of Separation‑of‑Powers Doctrine

extracted.value: U.S. Constitution, Article I, Sections 1 and 4
